div.l: While thou haste as a cowarde ben agaste
Ye fals harlotte quod the miller haste
Thou shalte be dede by goddes dignitee
A fals clerke fals traytour quod hee
Who durste ben so bolde to disparage
My doughter that ys com̄me of such lynage
And by the throte bolle he caught Aleyne
And he him hent despitously ageyne
And on the nose he smote him with his feste
Doun ranne the blode stremynge on his breste
And on the flore with nose and mouth tobroke
They walowe as doone twoo pigges in a poke
And vp they gone and doun̄ ayein anone
Tille that the miller spront at a stone
And doun̄ he fille bacwarde on his wife
That wiste no thinge of this grete strife
For she was falle in a slepe a litle wight
With Iohn the clerke that waked hir aright
And with the falle oute of hir slepe she breide
Helpe holy croys of bromeholme she seide
In manus tuas lorde I the calle
Awake symonde the fende is on me falle
Myn herte is broken helpe I am but dede
There lythe vpon my wombe and on myn hede
Help simkyn for thise two clerkes fight
This Iohn sterte vp as faste as eủer he might
And grasped by the walles too and froo
To finde a staffe and she sterte vp alsoo
And knewe the estres better thenne did Iohn
And by the walle a staffe she founde a none
And sawe a litle shymeringe of a light
For at an hole in shone the mone bright
And by that light she sawe hem both twoo
But sekerly she ne wiste who was whoo
But as she sawe a white thinge in her yie
And whenne she gan this white thinge espye
She wende the clerke had wered a voluper
And with hir staffe she drough ay nere ⁊and nere
And wende haue hitte this Aleyne at the fulle
And smote the miller on the pilled sculle
That doun̄ he goth and cried harowe I dey
Thise clerkes bette him well and let him lye
And greithen hem and toke her hors anone
And eke her mele and on their wey they gone
And at the mille yet thei tooke her cake
Of halfe a busshell floure well ybake
Thus is the proude miller well y bette
And hath loste the grinding of his whete
And paide for the souper eủery dele
Of Aleyne and of Iohn that bet him wele
His wife is swyued and his doughter als
Loo swich itte is a miller to ben fals
And therfore this ꝓprouerbe is seid full sothe
He canne nat wene wele that euyll dothe
A gyloure shall him self begiled bee
And god that sitteth high in maiestee
Save alle this companye grete and smale
Thus haue I quyt the miller in my tale
The mynyster ⁊and the norissh vnto vices
Which that men clepe in englissh ydelnesse
That porter at the gate is off delices
To eschiewe and by hir contrary her oppresse
That is to seyn by liefull besynesse
Welle aughten we to done all oure entente
Leste the fende thurgh ydelnesse vs hente
For he that with his thousande cordes slye
Continuelious vs wayteth to be clappe
Whenne he may man with idelnesse espye
He canne so subtilly cacch hem in his trappe
That tille a man be hente by the lappe
He is nat ware the fende hath him in honde
Well aught vs wretches ydelnesse wᵗithstonde
And though men neuer dradden for to dye
Yette men sene by reason doutelesse
That ydelnesse is hoten slogardye
Of which there commeth neuere gode encres
